5215813/5215021/5237880.title: Horses
5215813/5215021/5237880.text:
HorsesEvery farmer in my district has a horse.The stable fodder they get is oats hay straw and potatoes.  If a horse has a cough they will give him straw they say that straw will cure it.The people say that washed potatoes is very bad for a horse.  The people do not wash them but they leave the clay on them when they are going to give the potatoes to the horse.  No man in my district has goats but they have a lot of sheep.  The farmers have their sheep in the hills in spring and in summer.  And in the month of October the sheep come down themselves from hills and the
(continues on next page)

4922163/4857482/5237904.title: The Care of Our Farm Animals

5215813/5215231/5238926.title: Farm Animals
5215813/5215231/5238926.text:
These are the animals that are on our farms, cows, calves, sheep, lambs, pig an ass, a foal, dogs, cats, cocks,  hens, ducks and geese.Two of our cows have names, "Black Heifer," and "Sore Tite". The "Sore Tite" is so called because she had a sore  tite once.When we are driving cows or calves we say "Doirs."The cow-house is called The Big Barn. It is divided in to two parts by a
(continues on next page)

5235144/5222685/5239487.title: Farm Animals
5235144/5222685/5239487.text: The names of the farm and domestic animals at home are.

5235144/5222703/5239505.title: Farm Animals
5235144/5222703/5239505.text: The animals we have on our farm are cattle, sheep, cows. The cows.

5235144/5222746/5239579.title: Farm Animals
5235144/5222746/5239579.text: Farm Animals      12-5-1938There are a great many names of animals in the world such as Fanie or Polly nearly ever

5236102/5231867/5239945.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5236102/5231867/5239945.text:
The following are the animals we have at home, cow, hens, donkey. When driving cows we say How, How and when driving calves in or out of a field we usually say Suk, Suk. I have heard the following names called for cows, Daisy, Kitty, Tut, and Braddy. The cow house is made of timber and roofed with corrugated iron. The cows are tied to stakes with chains and ropes, the cows are tied by the necks to the stakes and sometimes by the horns. Every May-Eve the branch of a rowan tree is put over the door of the cow-house. It is supposed to bring luck on the cows.We say Tuk, Tuk when calling
(continues on next page)

5236089/5229945/5240182.title: Farm Animals
5236089/5229945/5240182.text:
The animals we keep on our farm are cattle, sheep, pigs, a horse, and a donkey. We keep two cows in our farm. The names of the cows are the "black cow" and the "snowball". When I am driving the cows I saw habhra! habha! to them. We call the calfs to the milk by saying suck, suck to them. The name of the cow-house is the cabin. We put straw under our cows to bed them. We tie the cows with a strong
(continues on next page)

5236102/5232029/5240197.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5236102/5232029/5240197.text:
The following are the list of Animals on our farm:1. Cows2. Calves3. Donkeys4. A Horse5. Dogs6. Cats7. Hens8 Ducks9. Geese10. Turkeys11. PigsThe names of cows which I heard are: Dolly, Blackeen, Blue, Grey, Buldy, Mackey, Brady, Brassil, etc.When I drive cows to or from a field I say "How-How". When we call calves we say "Suck-Suck".The cow house is made of cement and covered with iron. The cows are tied with chains to cement piers. The house is called a stall. When we
(continues on next page)

5236089/5229976/5240244.title: Farm Animals
5236089/5229976/5240244.text:
The animals we keep on our farm are cattle, sheep, pigs, a horse and a donkey. We keep three cows in our farm. The names of the cows are the snowball, the magpie, and the grey cow. When I am driving the cows I say habha ! habha ! to them. When we are calling our calves to their milk we say suck suck to them,The names of
(continues on next page)

5236089/5230005/5240263.title: Farm Animals
5236089/5230005/5240263.text:
We keep sheep, cows and pigs. We also keep horses and donkeys. One is called the black cow and the other is called the white cow. When my father is driving the cows he says habha! habha! When we are calling the calfs we say suck! suck!. We call our cow-house the cows stable.We put straw under our cows and calfs for bedding. We
(continues on next page)

5236089/5230131/5240340.title: Farm Animals
5236089/5230131/5240340.text:
We keep cows, sheep, pigs horses, donkeys and goats  One cow is called the Big Cow. Another one is called the Old cow. Another one is called the strawberry cow. When I am driving the cows I say habha ! habha!We call our calfs the Big cows calf the old cows calf and the strawberrys cows calf. When I am calling the calfs to there drink I say suck! suck!
(continues on next page)

5236089/5230163/5240362.title: Farm Animals
5236089/5230163/5240362.text:
The animals we keep on our farm are cattle, sheep, pigs, a horse, and an ass. We keep two cows also. The names of the cows are the polly cow and the "bracket" cow. When I am driving the cows I say habha! habha!The following are the names we call our calves:- the suck calves, the heifer calves and the bullocks. We
(continues on next page)

5236102/5232088/5240394.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5236102/5232088/5240394.text: The cow. The cow's name is kull kull.The Donkey. The donkey's name is Bill.She is a Craddy cow. She is tied around the horns with a rope. The cow house is made with timber and covered with corrugated iron. Put a horse shoe in a cow house is unlucky. It is said that if you threw away milk it would be for some use for one in another country. When a woman is calling hens she will say tuk tuk, and the hens would come to her. Hatching hens are left under the nest for about a week and when the chickens pick the shell and then they come out. There is a mark put in the eggs with pencil to show that they were hatched.

5235142/5221886/5241036.title: Ainmhithe na Feirme
5235142/5221886/5241036.text:
13adh Mí na Nodhlag 1937Ainmhidhthe na FeirmeSiad na h-ainmhidhthe a bhíos ar an bhfeirm, an bhó, an laogh, an t-asal, na caoirigh, an capall, muca, cearca, lachain, mada, agus cat. Nuair a bhíonn muid ag glaodhach ar an mbó tughann muid "beathain" uirre. Nuair a bhíonn muid ag glaodhach ar an laog tughann muid "súc suc" air. Nuair a bhíonn muid ag glaodhach ar an asal tughann muid "bess" air. Nuair a bhíonn muid ag glaodhach ar na caoirigh tughann muid "teamhain" ortha. Nuair a bhíonn muid ag glaodhach ar an gcapall tughann muid túd air. Nuair a bhíonn muid ag glaodhach ar na muca tughann muid "fros fros." Nuair a bhíonn muid ag glaodhach ar an gcear tughann muid "tuic" uirthi.
(continues on next page)

5235142/5221946/5241307.title: Ainmhithe na Feirme
5235142/5221946/5241307.text:
13adh Mí na Nodhlag 1937Is iad seo na h-ainmhidhthe feirme ata againn ag baile, bó, gabhainn, laogh, capall, asal, caoirig, mada, cat, cearca, muca. Nuair a bíonn muid a glaodach ortha tugann muid ainm fa leith ortha le go dtuigfeadh gach ceann aca muid. Tugann muid "beithin" ar an mbó, "Suichin" ar an laog agus bulan ar an ngabhainn, " "tuigin" ar an gcapall, "bess" ar an asal, "Seaibhin" ar na caoirigh, "bute" ar an mada, "pes, pes" ar an gcat, tiuch tuich ar na cearca, nuch, nuch, nuch ar na muca, Nuair a bitear da dtiomaint deirtear "huirt" leis an mbó, leis an asal High-ass, leis an gcapall go-on, leis an mada go-out, leis an gcat Skut, leis na cearca sea-sí agus deirtear leis na muca fág-seo. Sin iad na h-ainmeacha
(continues on next page)

5235142/5221995/5241684.title: Na Fataí
5235142/5221995/5241684.text:
(continued from previous page)
ortha le iad a choinneál slán ó’n dúbh. Nuair a bhíonn na barranna críonaighthe annsin, tosuightear dá mbaint. Nuair bhíonn siad bainte pioctar iad agus cuirtear abhaile iad le asal no capall, acha na fataí a bhíonn le h-aghaidh síolta cuirteari bpoll iad ins an ngarrdha más gainimh atá ann agus mar ab’eadh cuirtear I bpoll ar an muirbheach iad. Siad na cineál fataí a fhásann ins an oileán seo ná, dates, atan, bannes, atan, baitns, bpicutes agus kettpicks achc siad na dates na fataí is fearr a fhásann ann.



Ainmhidhthe na Feirme 1 adh Nodhlaig 1937. Siad na h-ainmidhte feirme atá again ag baile ná, bó, laoi, asal, caoirigh, gabhair, cearca, lachain, muca agus mada. Nuair bhidhtear leo ‘hoirde’ agus nuair a bhidhtear ag glaodhach ar a’ mbó séard a deirtear “betín” agus nuair a bhidhtear ag glaodhach ar an laoi séard a deirtear “suicín”.
(continues on next page)

5235142/5222042/5241758.title: Na Fataí
5235142/5222042/5241758.text:
(continued from previous page)
mar sin go dtí tús Feabhra.



Is iad na h-ainmhidhthe atá againn ar an bhfeirm ag baile ná, an capall, an tasal, an bhó, an bulán, an laoigh, na gabhair, na caoirigh, na cearca, na lachain, an cat, an mada agus na muca. Nil aon ainm againn ar an gcapall, ná ar an asal, ná ar na gabhair acht ar an sean-ghabhar agus gabhar na nadharc gcama. Tá corr ainm againn ar na caoirigh, caora an mhuirbhid, caora an chois bhriste, an chaora chrosach agus an chaora mhór chrosach, an tuasgán, caora an uain duibh, an chaora dhubh, an chaora liath, an tuasgán mór, an tuan atá gan beárradh, na muilt agus an reithe. Nuair a bhíonn muid ag tiomáint na mbó deireann muid "suirdín" leis an mbulán agus leis an laoigh "suirdín".  Deireann muid "Hí-ha" leis an gcapall . "Go on Jack leis an asal, "sha" leis an gabhair agus na caoirigh, "scut" leis an gcat, "Scout" leis an madadh agus "freshin" leis na muca.
(continues on next page)

5236102/5232161/5241798.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5236102/5232161/5241798.text:
The following is a list of the animals on our farm.One donkey,One cow,calf,cat,hens.The names of the cows that I heard are: Tut, Spot, Puchedy and Kit. When I am driving the cow I say How, How, and when we are driving calves we say Suck off. Our cows house is made timber and zinc. The cow is tied to a bail with a chain. Her house is called a stall.When they are calling the hens they say Tuck, tuck. If two different kinds of eggs are hatched under the same hen they mark one lot of eggs with the
(continues on next page)

5235184/5227743/5241815.title: Ainmhithe na Feilme
5235184/5227743/5241815.text: (1) An bó,  An Coinin(2) An capall(3) An caóire.(4) An gé(5) An Lachann(6) An cearch(7) An cath(8) An mádhadh(9) An cú(10) An ásal.(11) An gábhann,(12) An gabhar(13) An Much(14) An ceart pranncach.(15) An Carabh(16) An Culán(17) An Culach Franncac

5235184/5227807/5241865.text: (1) An capall.(2) An bo.(3) An gé.(4) An lacan(5) An madad(6) An chearch.(7) An cú.(8) An caoire.(9) An Gabhann(10) An t-asal.(11) An gábhar(12) An much.(13) An Tarbh.(14) An Coláin(15) An Cath(16) An Ceare Franncac.An Culac Franncac.

5236102/5232199/5241881.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5236102/5232199/5241881.text:
The list of farm and domestic animals I have at home:CowsCalvesPigsA HorseDogsCatsWhen we are driving the cows out to the field we say "How How". The cows house is usually made of pillars and corrugated iron and inside are pillars with chains or ropes attached to them to tie around the cows neck. When we call the calves to come to us we say "Suck Suck". There are some names for horses such as Tom and Molly and Harry. We have two dogs and seven cats at home the names of the dogs are Rover and Shep. When we are driving horses or donkeys we say go on. When we call pigs we say "Wat Wat".
(continues on next page)

5235184/5227862/5241938.title: Ainmhithe - Na Rudaí atá ar an Fheilm

5235142/5222092/5241966.title: Ainmhithe na Feirme
5235142/5222092/5241966.text:
Is iad na h-ainmhidhte feirme tá againn ag baile :ná bó, laogh, gabhainn, caora, gabhar, capall, asail, cearca agus muca madad agus cat. Is iad seo na h-ainmeacha a tugtar ortha.Tugthar "Beitín" ar an mbhó.Tugthar "Sucaí" ar an laogh.Tugthar " Bróiní" at an gcapall.Tugthar "Bas" ar an asal.Tugthar " Seoín" ar an gcaoirigh agus ar an gabhar. Tugthar "Fus" "Fus" ar na muca.Tugthar "Spota" ar an madad.Tugthar "Poplín" ar an cat.Nuair a bíos duine dá dtiomáint is iad seo na h-ainmeacha a thughadh sé ortha."h-árd" ar an mbhó."hó amach" leis an gcapall agus leis an asal."Seoín" leis an caoirigh agus leis an gabhar."Seo leis na cearca.
(continues on next page)

5236102/5232240/5242137.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5236102/5232240/5242137.text:
These are the animals we have at home.CowsDonkeyChickensTurkeysHorsesPigsGeeseDogsCalvesHensDucksI have cows called the following names: Black, Kit, Speckled, Brady, Freasy, Kicken, Polly, Short horn, Punty. In driving them in or of the field we say how how. They are bailed in the stall. The cow puts her head in between two bails and one of the bails is closed in and is caught with a hook. The walls of the stall are built of stone. The roof is slanted, it is covered with corrugated iron.The horses are tied in the stable by the neck.
(continues on next page)

5236102/5232293/5242250.title: Festival Customs
5236102/5232293/5242250.text:
(continued from previous page)
animals.



CowsCalvesHensHorsesDonkeyDucksThese are the following names for cows - Purty, Brady, Fancy, Redeens, Strawberry, Kerry Block Pet. This is what they say when driving cows - how how. These are the names of the horses - Dally, Molly, Polly, Harry. When driving horses we say go on or when driving donkeys we say go on
(continues on next page)

5235142/5222174/5242289.title: Ainmhithe na Feirme
5235142/5222174/5242289.text: Is íad seo na hainmhidhthe atá againn ar an bhfeirm ag baile, bó gabhainn laog, capall, asal caoirigh mada cait cearca agus muca. Is íad seo na h-ainmeacha a tugtar ortha. Tugtar "Beithín" ar an mbó, "Suchín" ar an laog, " Bróin" ar an gcapaill, agus ar an asal, "Seóin ar na caoirigh. "Topy" air an mada, agus "Póilín" agus "Pussy" air na cait, tuich, tuich ar na cearca agus tú, tú, ar na mucha. Nuair a bhíos na fir da dtiomaint abríonn sé leis an gCapaill "hó amach", agus an rud ceadna leis an gchuid eile freisin acht amháin an t-asal deirtear leis sin h-ia-as. Cuirtear mar easair faoí an asal nuair  a bhíos sé sa gcró féir tuighe agus raithneach. Annsin go minich cuirtear crumeasg air le é coinneál.

5235184/5228026/5242301.title: Ainmhithe - Na Rudaí atá ar an Fheilm

5235184/5228056/5242330.title: Ainmhithe - Na Rudaí atá ar an Fheilm

5235184/5228100/5242392.title: Ainmhithe - Na Rudaí atá ar an bhFeilm

5235184/5228136/5242443.title: Ainmhithe - Na Rudaí Atá ar an bhFeilm

5236102/5232362/5242451.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5236102/5232362/5242451.text: When women are calling the hens to their dinner they say tuk, tuk and the hens will come to them. Hatching eggs are left under a hen for three weeks. The chickens in the shell will be nipping at the shell. Then they will come out. When hatching eggs are layed with other eggs there is a mark put on them with a pencil to show where the hatching eggs are.When a man is driving his cows he says how, how. There are also other names for cows such as Daisy, Braddy, Short-Horn, and Polly.

5236102/5232425/5242562.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5236102/5232425/5242562.text: These are the animals we have at home.CowsCalvesHensDucksHorsesPigsChickensDogsAssesDucksTurkeysI have cows called the following names: Kerry, Blue, Black, Guerin, Crowley, Grey Heifer, Blue Heifer.In driving the cows in and out of a field we say how how. The walls of the stall are built of stone. It is covered with corrugated iron. There are walls between every cow and the cows are tied by the neck with chains.

5236102/5232489/5242610.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5236102/5232489/5242610.text:
The following are the animals we have at home - hens, chickens, asses and a goat. When driving cows the people usually say How, How, and when driving calves they say Suk, Suk. I have heard the following names called to cows - Tut, Tom, Kitty, Daisy, Kerry, Smollen, Rose, Braddy and Polly. The cow-house is made of cement and is covered with corrugated iron, and there is an airhole left inside to let in air. In this district the cow is tied by the neck with a chain on to a pillar made for the purpose. Every May-Eve there is a branch of rowan put inside the cows' door to bring luck. When calling hens we say Tuk, Tuk, ducks feed, feed, geese baddy,
(continues on next page)

5260399/5246447/5260644.title: Care of Farm Animals
5260399/5246447/5260644.text:
We have the following farm animals at home: two cows, four calves, one horse, three pigs, one cat and one dog, and forty sheep. We have no special name on them. When driving out the cows I say "How up", to them. We call the cow house a "byre". The byre is thatched and is about thirty feet long and twelve feet broad. A wooden manger runs along one side. It is divided into stalls for the cows. There are iron
(continues on next page)

5260399/5246494/5260690.title: Care of Farm Animals
5260399/5246494/5260690.text: We have the following farm animals;- two cows, one horse, one ass, three cattle, two calves, seven pigs, one dog, two cats. We have no special name on the cows. When driving out the cows I say "How up", to them. We call the cow house a "byre". The byre is thatched and is about thirty feet long and twelve feet wide. A wooden manger runs along one side.

5260399/5246519/5260708.title: Care of Farm Animals
5260399/5246519/5260708.text:
We have the following farm animals at home: four cows, three horse, one ass,   forty sheep, fourteen cattle, four calves, six pigs, two dogs, and two cats.We have no special name on them. When driving out the cows I say "How up", to them. We call the cow house a "byre". The byre is thatched and is about thirty feet long and twelve feet broad. A wooden manger runs along one side. It is divided into stalls for the cows. There are iron
(continues on next page)

5260399/5246618/5260857.title: 'As Bad as Robert'
5260399/5246618/5260857.text:
(continued from previous page)
to say."Tá sé chomh maith le Riobard"



We have the  following farm animals at home.

5260428/5251864/5261240.title: Livestock
5260428/5251864/5261240.text:
We have six cows at home.  They eat hay and grass.  They are bedded with straw and litter.  They are tied with chains.  All of them have names.  One of them is called one horn, another is the red cow, the white cow, the speckled cow, the black cow and the roan cow.  We have eleven calves and two horses.  One of them is called the red horse and the other is called the black horse.  We feed them on hay.  We have also nine sheep.
(continues on next page)

5260428/5251889/5261277.title: Livestock
5260428/5251889/5261277.text:
We keep three cows and five calves at home.  We have names on them all which are, the grey, the red and the short-horn.  We keep them in the cow-house in the winter.  We bail them in with two beams of timber.  The cow goes in between the two beams and it's tied on the top.It is a sign of luck to keep a bottle and some holy water in the house and to put some in every year when the cows are going in.  Whenever the cows change it is said it would be lucky to shake the holy water about the house.  The names we have on the calves are the white-head, the black, the red and the grey.  We put straw under the cows for a bed
(continues on next page)

5260428/5251918/5261368.title: Livestock
5260428/5251918/5261368.text:
We have five cows which are kept in the cow-house during the winter nights.  They are tied with chains.  In olden times cows were tied with a gad made of osiers and a rope or sugan.We have three horses, two working ones and a foal.  The two working horses are kept in a stable during the winter nights.  One horse's name is Dick.  We call the other the pony.  Dick is a Scotch horse and the pony is an Irish bred pony.We have four
(continues on next page)

5260428/5251936/5261398.title: Livestock
5260428/5251936/5261398.text:
The animals on our farm are, the cow, the horse, the ass, the sheep, the goat, the pig, and the dog, the most faithful of all the animals.Of all the animals mentioned above by far the most useful is the cow, because she supplies us with milk and butter for our own use and for market.  We have one remarkable cow named Aoarccim, the breed of which is on the farm for over fifty years, as they produce far more butter than any other cow.  There is a remarkable
(continues on next page)

5260428/5251961/5261418.title: Livestock
5260428/5251961/5261418.text:
The names of the animals in our farm are, the cow, the horse, the sheep, the ass, the pig, the goat and the dog.  Of all the animals in our farm the cow is the most useful.  The names of our cows are the magpie, the blue, the gray, the roan, the white, and the Kerry.  We tie our cows with chains.  We have one horse.  We feed our horse and cows on hay. We give the horse oats every day.  We give the horse and cows straw for bedding.  We have sixteen
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252002/5261462.title: Livestock
5260428/5252002/5261462.text:
The names of the animals on our farm are cows, calves, horses, pigs, goats and fowl.  We have six cows named Poll, white cow, black cow, strawberry cow, red Kerry and magpie.  When the cows come in they are tied in the cowshed with chains tied to poles.  They have a nice bed of straw and a manger of hay.  The cows are milked every morning and evening at a certain hour.  Everyone helps at the milking seated on three-legged stool
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252039/5261492.title: Livestock
5260428/5252039/5261492.text: We have two horses.  The names which we call them are black Bess and flying fox.  Black Bess was never stopped by a fence.  She is a good worker, but a great rogue, and must be chained at all times when she is on grass.  Flying fox is very quiet.  We have three whitehead calves and four others.  The white-head calves are a good breed of cattle.  They are in a good condition and thrive well.  We have three cows and two spring heaters.  The names which

5260428/5252066/5261522.title: Livestock
5260428/5252066/5261522.text:
Most people have many animals such a asses horses and all kinds of cattle.  In olden times, it was said fairies used to play on the borders of an Irish lake.Each fairy had golden hair.One fairy had a white hound and before her she drove a cow.  One day the cow went from the fairy and an old farmer caught her.  She was with his own.  There was no black cow seen those times.  Since that day the old farmer grew rich.  She gave milk to all that came for it, and if they milked
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252099/5261558.title: Names of Places
5260428/5252099/5261558.text:
(continued from previous page)
a man found dead in it, and his name was Macdonnell.  It was called Ballymacdonnell ever afterwards.



We have many animals on our farm.  We have cows, horses, sheep, pigs, calves, hens, and ducks.  The house we have for the cows is called the cow house.  They know their own places, and they never go into another place.  They are tied in stalls.  Every cow has a different name; one cow is called the white cow, another is called
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252130/5261675.title: Livestock
5260428/5252130/5261675.text:
3rd Feb 1937LivestockA great many animals belong to the farm namely the cow, the horse, the donkey the sheep, the calf, the pig the dog and many other small animals.  There are also some birds on the farm, namely, hens, ducks turkeys geese, We have five cows called by a different name, the blue cow, the Kerry, the short horn, the speckled cow, the roam. Our cows are tied with chain around the neck or horns, in the cow-house during winter there they are fed with hay
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249570/5261815.text:
(continued from previous page)
potatoesdugthe ground,wooden ploughplough



There is a list of the domstic animals in our farm, at home, manly the cow, horse  donkey, sheep, pig, calf, goat and the dog.We have names on the most of our cows as family, beauty, polly, speckled ect; When we
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249603/5261851.text:
(continued from previous page)

The names of our domestic farm animals are the cows, calves, pigs, goats and sheep. The cows have got names such as Báinín, The Black cow, The Spotted cow, and many other names also. When driving the cows we say Suck, Suck, Suck,
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249636/5261882.title: Festival Customs
5260407/5249636/5261882.text:
(continued from previous page)
they dance, the people of the house give them some money and they go from house to house during the day.Correctionsyour your your

5260407/5249688/5261935.text:

Water is poured in during the process to cool it. Butter milk is mostly used for bread making and some of it for drinking. There is no mark on the side or bottom of the churn.CorrectionsThere is no mark on the side and about once a fortnight

5260407/5249729/5261985.title: The Care of Our Farm Animals
5260407/5249729/5261985.text:
The domestic animals on the farm are the cows, horses, pigs and calfs. Every cow has a certain name such as "the white heifer", "the big blue" and "the maol cow". Usually when people are driving the cows they saw (how how) and when they are calling the calves they say ("suck" "suck"). The house where the cows sleep is called a stall. Some cows are tied to bails to
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249767/5262009.title: Festival Customs
5260407/5249767/5262009.text:
(continued from previous page)
and put their mouths into the water to try to get the apple. If they get the apple they can keep it. There is a cake also made on Halloween. A ring a thimble and other things are put into it. Children find great pleasure in playing these games.Corrections.Customs.



The farm and
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249861/5262061.text:
(continued from previous page)
commonly called sappers.On St John's night most people light bonfires in honour of St John.



The only animal we have at home is the cow. The cow we have has got no name.
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249923/5262097.title: Festival Customs
5260407/5249923/5262097.text:
(continued from previous page)

5260407/5249946/5262121.text:

There is a list of domestic animals in our farm such as the cow, horse, goat, sheep and calf. There are names on our cows such as Purty, Athae, Polly, Beauty. When we are driving the cows we say "how" "how" "how". The cows are tied with bales
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249970/5262183.title: Proverbs
5260407/5249970/5262183.text:
(continued from previous page)
Don't be hard and don't be soft. Don't desert your friend for your own share. He who has a trade has an estate.A stitch in time saves nine.



The farm and domestic animals at home are the cows, pigs, sheep, goats, and calves. The cows have got
(continues on next page)

5260407/5249993/5262200.title: The Care of Our Farm Animals
5260407/5249993/5262200.text:
The chief farm animals are the cow the horse the pig the pony and the ass and the domestic animals are the cat and the dog. When we are driving the cows we say 'How' 'How'. When we are driving the calves we say 'suck' 'suck'. In the cow house the cows are tied to bales. The cow-house is called a stall. The horses are kept in stables
(continues on next page)

5260407/5250029/5262247.title: The Care of Our Farm Animals
5260407/5250029/5262247.text:
The most common of our animals is the cow. We say How. How. The other farm animals are the sheep pigs and goats. Cows are generally tied by the neck and horns. People keep holy water in the stalls, to bring luck on the stock. Horses are generally hair clipped before they are put in, in winter. People exchange eggs with one another, cows have
(continues on next page)

5260407/5250053/5262264.title: Churning
5260407/5250053/5262264.text:
(continued from previous page)
the churn.



Most farmers have a good lot of cattle in the farm such as cows calves pigs horses sheep and other animals. Most of them have got names
(continues on next page)

5260407/5250077/5262276.title: The Care of Our Farm Animals
5260407/5250077/5262276.text:
We have fourteen cows, twelve calves two horses two sows nine bonhams and a donkey. All the cows have got names. When driving the cows we say "How" How". The cows house is made of cement floor and is covered with iron. The cows are tied to the wall with chains which are made of strong wire and are made at home in Ireland.The horses are kept in stables in winter and are fed on hay and oats. The horses are shod by the local smiths and are clipped
(continues on next page)

5260407/5250097/5262306.title: Holy Wells
5260407/5250097/5262306.text:
(continued from previous page)
are known to be cured.When the invalids are leaving the well after performing roundes they leave some (articles) relic there such as bottles of holy water, holy pictures, or some religious article.CorrectionsBrigids, poophided, such, water, religion

5260434/5252906/5262838.title: Names of Animals
5260434/5252906/5262838.text: 48               Names of animals                       31st of March,1938All the calves and yearlings are called by saying "Such Such"and the horses is calle by saying "pshew pshew".Hens are called by saying "Thewe Thewe" and ducks are called by saying "Feed Feed".

5260470/5255929/5262857.title: Hens
5260470/5255929/5262857.text:
We have thirty hens at home and one cock  one of the hens name is Poll. We feed them three times a day with oats. In the hen house there are four places for the hens to lay. We put ashes on the floor of the hen house. Some of the hens clock every year and they are put down to hatch. Thirteen eggs are put under each hen and it takes three weeks for the chickens to come out. They are not fed for a day. Before they are fed the little hard lump is
(continues on next page)

5260445/5252935/5262872.title: Cows
5260445/5252935/5262872.text:
Nowadays when a person wants a cow "he lets up" a heifer, but in days gone by, the old people used to choose a cow with a white udder. they used say if a cow had a white udder, she would be good for milking.Usually if a cow's milk is thin, and bad for colouring tea, it is good for butter. Long ago, great commotion would be about buying a cow, nowadays it is almost unnoticed. If a certain man went to a fair to buy a cow all the neighbours would go with to make the "dealing," and in the evening he would treat them all in
(continues on next page)

5260445/5252936/5262874.title: Cows
5260445/5252936/5262874.text:
(continued from previous page)
72a public -house.When a cow would calf long ago ,the people of the house would do around the milk or the name they used call it was "beastings." Then the person who got it would say "May God increase your store" or often "That your cow may be [?] times better this time next year.

Then the person who got it would say "May God increase your store" or often "That your cow may be [?] times better this time next year." 1) One horn2) Jack3) Brodericks'4) Guney5) The blue6) The PollyThe old people had bad ways to tie their cow. They used have posts drove down through the ground, and sugans twisted around
(continues on next page)

5260470/5256059/5262971.title: Pigs
5260470/5256059/5262971.text:
We have one sow and her name is "Muck".  She is kept in a little house beside a lane it is made up of two apartments the place where she sleeps and the place where she is fed.  The sow has about two litters in the year.   When the sow is farrowing there is always a man with her.   You have to stay up for two or three
(continues on next page)

5260470/5256061/5262972.title: Hens
5260470/5256061/5262972.text: We have about thirty hens at home, they are fed on potatoes pollard and oats.  We call one "Topping" and another "Speck".  When my mother is going to put down a hen to hatch she puts a horseshoe under the box for luck.  There is a ring put on the cock's leg and a bit of a copper wire tied to the ring.

5260488/5259243/5263155.title: Horses
5260488/5259243/5263155.text:
Any person about here who has a horse has a stable for him.Any day that a horse does be carting turf he always gets a bucket of corn to eatSometimes they cut the mane off the horses when it does be too long.About here the people always
(continues on next page)

5260488/5259303/5263188.title: Old Sayings
5260488/5259303/5263188.text:
(continued from previous page)
two.You always get goods goods in a small packit



There is an Animal called a cow.There is another called a bull.There is another called a bullock.There is another called a heifer. We have a cow called Quinn.When you are trying to cap
(continues on next page)

5260488/5259309/5263193.title: Horses
5260488/5259309/5263193.text:
The house the horse is in is called a stable. The food the horse gets is corn and hay.When the horse's shoes get worn you need to go to the blacksmith to get new shoes on you need to clip them very often.You need to clip the tail and mane.When you are calling the hens
(continues on next page)

5260488/5259407/5263284.title: Names of Animals
5260488/5259407/5263284.text:
Here are a lot of cows. The Short horn is a name of a cow. The Rony. The Maoilín. The Horney. The people say that the yellow cows are a better breed than the black cows. If you want to stop a cow you say to her “Theach. Theach and she will know what you say. When you want to put her walking you say. “Go on or that with you” The names
(continues on next page)

metadata.Collector: Anna Ní Méallaigh, alternative name Annie Melley

5260488/5259579/5263403.title: Cows
5260488/5259579/5263403.text: There are plenty of cows round here. The bedding the people put under their cows is straw and sometimes they put ferns. Its with a chain the most of the people round here tie them. I never saw anything being in the byre for luck except holy water.One of our cows is called Kate

5260488/5259662/5263523.title: Horses
5260488/5259662/5263523.text:
There are not many horses around here. Hay is the most thing the horses get. This is the way they call the cows “Té”  “Té” This is the way they call the the calves and pigs ‘Sucky’ ‘Sucky’.“Súg’ they call the pigs. This is the way they call the hens “Juck” “Juck”. For the ducks they call “Feet Feet”. This is for turkeys ‘Pee’ ‘Pee’
(continues on next page)

5260466/5255233/5264983.title: Na Cearca
5260466/5255233/5264983.text:
Ta cuigh cearcha déag againn sa baile. Níl aon ainmhneacha orta ach nuair a bíonn mo mátháir ag tabhairt biadh doibh tuich! tuich! tuich! a deireann se. Ta cró beag acha doibh féin. "The hen house", a tughaimíd air. Na leacain:- Fiach" Fiach"! Fiach! bíonn siad istigh i gcró beag féin in-aice cró na gcearch. Eanlaite beag cosamhail le preacán is ead na leachan.Na geadna:- Nuair a bíonn mo máthair ag glaoidh
(continues on next page)

5260466/5255326/5265030.title: Féilí na Bliana
5260466/5255326/5265030.text:
(continued from previous page)
dtagann an puca an oidhche sin, agus loiteann se na smeara. Deirtear go dtagann na sideóga an oidhche sin.



Ta ocht mbó againn sa bhaile. Seo leanas na h ainmneacha ata orta:- Voughans, Meegans, Mees, OBriens, Dohertys, Laughans, Neagles, agus Young Mees, tughtar na ainmhneacha sin ortha mar sin
(continues on next page)

5260466/5255506/5265130.title: Féilí na Bliana
5260466/5255506/5265130.text:
(continued from previous page)
craobh glas ós cíonn na doirse.



Tá dhá mbó againn sa baile sé an ainm atá ortha ná an bó bán agus "Tail off" a tughamar ortha. Bíonn
(continues on next page)

5260445/5253058/5265863.title: Cows
5260445/5253058/5265863.text:
17                   Cowslong ago the cow house was made of mud and roofed with scraws and hay. There was a stick stuck down in the ground a foot from the wall and each cow was tied to this pole with a sugan.Before the mud cabins came out the old people used tie the cow behind the door of the house.Then the cows used go mad when the water used rise to their brain and they used run off pure wild before them and if met a lake or river they would plunge in to it for they did not know where they
(continues on next page)

5260445/5253250/5267275.title: Cows
5260445/5253250/5267275.text:
59           Cows           10 -3 -38Long ago the cow houses were made of mud and roofed with scraws and hay. There was a stick stuck down in the ground a foot from the wall and each was tied to a pole with a sugan.Before the mud cabins came out the old people used tie the cow behind the door of the house. Then the cows used go mad when the water used rise to their brain and they used run off pure wild before them and if they met a lake or river they would plunge in to it for they did not know whee they were going and some people used shoot them.
(continues on next page)

5260445/5253251/5267276.title: Cows
5260445/5253251/5267276.text:
(continued from previous page)
60for they would never get out of it.



Names of cows.Sligo    =The rodger cow.Hatalán =The Blue cow.Kerrry cow= The backed horns.The red cow=The white head.Cuby cow     = The crow cow.Red cow       =The stripper.Black cow     =Polly cow. Short horn     =Whitey.Speckled cow =Pale cow.

5260445/5253364/5267625.title: Cows
5260445/5253364/5267625.text: 25                     Cows    11:3:38 Long ago they had cabins made of mus and heather.They used get stones and make a loose wall and fill the holes with mud and puddle.           They used have cans made of timber called pigans.Then they used the butter and get a rag and leave it on their heads .There was a ring of timber around the bucket and they used put it on there head and go twenty miles to town.

5260445/5253414/5268423.title: Cows
5260445/5253414/5268423.text:
37              Cows.11: 3: '38Some time ago the people were very much inclined to keep the Kerry breed of cows.The were small old fashioned looking littler animals and they were very hardy and easily fed.One certain man had six of those cows and had a name on each one,such as old Kerry,the Reddie,the Glinny,the Brownie ,the kicker and the old cripple.The reason she was called the cripple is because her two front feet were crooked.                The cabins they used have used be narrow and low and if a rafter chanced to break they used put a stick up against it inside in the middle of the cabin.They used put in the cows very carefully for fear they would hit the stick and knock it.if they did all the cabin
(continues on next page)

5236102/5270569/5275973.title: Festival Customs
5236102/5270569/5275973.text:
(continued from previous page)
chalk them in the coat.St John's night they make big bonfires.



CowsHorsesDonkeyCalvesHensDucksChickensGeeseThe names of the cows are Peggie, Buckley, Stack, Kitty, Magpie. How how for driving cows. Suck suck for calves. The cow house is made of tin. When calling the cows we say colly colly. The cows are tied with chains by the neck. Some people tie them around the horns with soft hemp tied on the stack. Tuck tuck for hens.
(continues on next page)

5236102/5270598/5275995.title: The Care of our Farm Animals

5236102/5270605/5276022.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5236102/5270605/5276022.text:
CowsDonkeysHensDucksChickensTurkeysHorseGeeseThese are the names of the cows Polly, Toot, Kitty, Tom, Mick, Peggy, Spot. How how driving cows. The cow house is made of tin and it is called a stall. The cows are tied with chains to pillars. The cows are tied from the neck, and legs and horns the tyings are made of chains. They are not made locly. There is a horse shoe put on the door to bring luck on the cows. The calls for animals
(continues on next page)

5236102/5270648/5276042.title: Festival Customs
5236102/5270648/5276042.text:
(continued from previous page)
it to God.Ash WednesdayAll the people go into the church for holy ashes and they make a cross on their forehead.



CowDonkeyHensWe have a Cow at home but we have no certain name for her. She is in wenter we call the house she is in a stall her tying is a rope tied to a stake driving down an the ground. We don't have the donkey
(continues on next page)

5275203/5271692/5277465.title: The Care of Our Farm Animals
5275203/5271692/5277465.text:
The animals on our farm are the following - pigs calves, cows and horses.Pigs are fed on presto, potatoes, and bran, and are let out in the field during the day.The cows are the most important animals on our farm for without them we would have no nice rich cream or milk.Our cows are tied in the houses during the Winter.They are tied by the horns with a chain. We have four
(continues on next page)

metadata.Collector: Brigid Ní Leatlobhair, local name Brighidh Ní Lálúar

5275203/5271783/5277574.title: Our Farm Animals
5275203/5271783/5277574.text:
Every farm consists of cows, horses, pigs, sheep and calves.To discern the cows from one another nick-names are put on them.The following names are on our cows:- "the blue cow" becaue she is of a greyish blue colour. "Cocked Horn" because she has very straight cocked horns. "Nell Tobin" because she was purchased from a person named Nell Tobin. "The Black Cow" thus called because she is black. "Lough Solus" because she was bought in Lough Solus.There is a big cow called "Old Kildrummy" because
(continues on next page)

5275203/5271834/5277582.title: The Care of our Farm Animals
5275203/5271834/5277582.text:
The animals which are kept on the farm next to my home are, milking cows, calves, pigs, horses and sheep.When the people are driving cows around this district, they use "hi", or "how".There is a big long cow-shed on the farm next to home. There are three big doors on that shed, and the shed is covered with galvenise, and painted red. That shed is also white-washed in-side, to keep away infectious diseases from the cows. It is owned by Mr Hutchinson.The way cows are tied nowadays is chains are tied
(continues on next page)

metadata.Collector: Máire de Paor, alternative name Mary Power

5215784/5209751/5277762.title: Twelve Days of Christmas
5215784/5209751/5277762.text:
(continued from previous page)
loaf-bread and currant cake.



Cows are tied in the barn at night from October, and calves from November until 1st May.Cows get straw and turnips and hay while tied in. In hard weather that is when there is snow or frost they require to get a mash. They are never let out in bad weather only for a drink.Sheep are kept in shelter during bad weather. They get turnips or oil-cake.Horses are never let out in winter. They are fed on hay and they get a little oats.Names generally called to cows are Poll, Sall, Straight horn, Crooked horn
(continues on next page)

5215784/5209860/5277842.title: Farm Animals
5215784/5209860/5277842.text: We have three cows at home. One is black and horny and another is grey and has horns too and one is a brown polly.We have a horse. Her name is Dolly. She is black and very quiet. The cows tyings are made of straw. There is a horse shoe put into the barn and the rope is tied on it. We have a dog. His name is Bruno. He is a good dog he brings the cows home for milking.

5215784/5209952/5278355.title: Farm Animals
5215784/5209952/5278355.text:
All the people around here rear cows and dry stock. We have three cows but we have names only on two of them which are the Horney and the Polly. We leave them out at night in summer time, but in winter time we put them into a barn which we call the cow-house.They are tied with shop chains and the chains are fastened on to stakes of timber with
(continues on next page)

5215784/5209955/5278356.title: The Care of Animals
5215784/5209955/5278356.text:
The cows get hay and straw during the winter. If they are giving milk they get a hot mash every night and morning to keep the milk with them. All the cows get turnips and cabbage during the winter.Young calves have to get milk and linseed until they are a couple of months old. When they grow older they get a little bit of hay and a couple of
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210007/5278403.title: Farm Animals
5215784/5210007/5278403.text:
We have three cows namely, Betty and Black cow and Cocked Horns. We have a stable for these cattle. We call it the cow byre.There are stakes standing by the wall. To these stakes the cows are tied with iron chains round their necks and sometimes they are tied with ropes. There  is a rack for each cow's hay. The stable is roofed with galvanized iron and plastered inside with mortar. There is a partition between the cow-byre and the thrashing barn. The partition is built of stone. It is white-washed.
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210063/5278438.title: Farm Animals
5215784/5210063/5278438.text:
We have three cows. We call one of them Maol dubh  one of them Polly and the other White Horns. My mother milks them every morning and evening. She milks a few strands of milk on the ground for the fairies and she makes the sign of the cross on the cow's side in order to bless her.Long ago the people used to tie a horse-shoe nail in a red rag on the cow's tail before she calved.
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210119/5278464.title: Farm Animals
5215784/5210119/5278464.text: We have four cows two horned cows and two black polly cows.We keep them in all night and out during day. We say "hursh" and "how" when driving them. Our cows are very good for milk. They give between two and three gallons each every day. We send some of the milk to the creamery in Balla and we give some milk to the calves and we churn the rest.

5215784/5210120/5278465.title: Hens
5215784/5210120/5278465.text:
We have about thirty hens at our house. They are black, grey, white, and red. They have a little house for themselves with perches going across from wall to wall and the hens roost on them every night. People do not like to put an even number of eggs under a hen because it is considered unlucky.
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210122/5278466.title: The Care of the Donkey
5215784/5210122/5278466.text:
We take great care of our donkey because he is a very useful animal. In Summer he is out in the field day and night. His feet are tied with a chain which has a hoop of iron at each end so that it will not hurt or cut his feet. After the donkey's days work he always gets a nice  bit of hay.In the winter he always gets a small feed of oats in the morning, after this he gets hay. At mid-day he gets a bundle of straw.
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210191/5278490.title: Farm Cows
5215784/5210191/5278490.text:
We have four cows and we call them Betty Jessie Polly and Hornie. When we are driving them we say "hursh" and "how" and when we want them to stand we day Prigeen.Before people have a cow to calf they tie a red tape around the cow's tail which means no one can make a bad eye at the cow.We tie the cows with a chain around the neck. The chain is fastened to
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210196/5278492.title: Care of a Horse
5215784/5210196/5278492.text:
Every one takes great care of horses because they are very useful. We have a barn for our horse in which he stays during the winter. In the summer he is out in the field night and day. In the winter we give the horse hay and oats in the morning. In the middle of the day we hive him Clarendo; and hay in the evening and oats or clarendo.After a hard day's work his legs get a
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210267/5278588.title: Farm Animals
5215784/5210267/5278588.text:
We have three cows at home namely:- Betta, Blue-cow and Black-cow. We have a stable for these animals we call it the "byre". There are stakes standing by the walls. To these stakes the cows are tied by a chain or rope. There is a rack for each cow's hay. There is a partition between the cow byre and the thrashing barn. They are roofed with galvanized iron and they are plastered inside
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210312/5278611.title: Farm Cows
5215784/5210312/5278611.text:
We have four cows at home. We have these names on them, the Poll, Maoilín, Strawberry, Grey horns. We have a barn especially for the cows. They are tied around the necks with chains or home made ropes. If the cows go into damage we put a Cromh Nasc, Boolin or side Lang on them. When a cow calves we put the sign of the cross around her with a coal to
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210313/5278612.title: Farm Cows
5215784/5210313/5278612.text:
(continued from previous page)
to bring good luck.When a person has finished milking, she puts the sign of the cross in the cow's hip and says "God bless you".



We have these names on them. If the cows go into damage we put a Crom Nase bootin or side lang on them. When a cow calves we put the sing of the cross around her with a coal to bring good luck.

5215784/5210315/5278614.title: Hens
5215784/5210315/5278614.text:
Hens are the birds most commonly reared around Fargureens where I live. Every one has thirty or forty hens. They lay about a score of eggs every day. We feed them three times a day, first feed in the morning of oats, next boiled potatoes and Indian meal and the evening a feed of raw Clarendo and Indian meal mixed. It is always lucky to put
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210380/5278641.title: Our Cows
5215784/5210380/5278641.text:
We have three cows and four calves on our farm. We call them the Bigle cow, Long Horns and White leg, the black calf, the Castlebar one, Short Horns and the suck calf. We drive them to the farm every day. When we are putting them into the field if they rush and start fighting, we say, "How, hursh, go back.
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252197/5278846.title: Livestock
5260428/5252197/5278846.text:
3rd February, 1938LivestockThe names of the animals on our farm are, the cow, the horse, the ass the sheep, the goat, the pig, and the dog.of The names of our cows are, the magpie, the kerry short horn, the roan, the black the blue, and the pole [?] agnus.The roan is the best cow we have. She had twin calves on two occasions.We tie our cows in stalls with chains around their necks. We
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252228/5278863.title: Livestock
5260428/5252228/5278863.text:
We have a great number of animals; cows, calves, an ass, a horse, pigs, a sow hens, ducks, geese, and turkeys. It is an old saying that if the milk is spilt when milking, that it is the good people that want it. When a person is driving the cows he says "how" "how". When he is calling the calves he says "suck" "suck"When he is driving the horse he says "go on" "go on" when he is calling the pigs or sow he says "deoc" "deoc" When he is calling the
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252249/5278875.title: Livestock
5260428/5252249/5278875.text:
There are many animals in our farm, namely cous, horses, cattle, calves and pigs. We have  five cows, namely the white, the Scariff, the crow-hill, the red and the sepeckled. The house in which they are kept by night in the Winter is called the cow-house. They are tied with chains around their neck. Each one of them knows her place. We keep the horse in the stable
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252266/5278882.title: Livestock
5260428/5252266/5278882.text:
We have five cows, three horses and seven calves. The cows are tied in the cow-house every night. They are tied with chains around the necks or horns. The blacksmith made those chains. Long ago the people tied the cows with gads. Sometimes they hung a piece of cloth in the cow-house for good luck. They said, if the milk was spilled when they were milking that it was the good people who wanted it and they were satisfied to let it go.One of our horses is very old. His name is Dick. He is twenty two years and does
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252299/5278901.title: Livestock
5260428/5252299/5278901.text:
We have three cows and two springing heifers. The name which we call them, are sprig, mureen, kery blue, heavy grey, light roan. The cow-house was an old dwelling some years ago. This house was without a roof for some years. My father put a roof on it about thirty years ago and made it quite warm and comfortable. Some time after he happened to have a cow  that was going to calv. It was in the middle of June and the other cows were out in grass. When the cow
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252316/5278910.title: Livestock
5260428/5252316/5278910.text:
We have six cows in our farm. The house where they stay at night is called the cowshed. They get hay to eat every night and straw is put in for a bed. In the morning they are milked and a fresh meal of hay is given to them. When the milking is over each cow gets a feed of mangolds and cotton meal. The milk is taken to the dairy and separated and is given to the calves. Then the hens are let out and there  are potatoes, bran and meal ready for them. When they hear the call of "chuck, chuck" they run to where the food is divided around. The
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252348/5278926.title: Livestock
5260428/5252348/5278926.text:
We have five cows at home. We tie our cows with chains. One cow is called the blue cow, another is called the speckled cow, another is called the Kerry cow and another is called the short horn cow. We have three horses. Two of them are trained. One of them is a young horse. We put a bridle on him for the first time. We keep shoes on our horses. One is a big horse. He draws very big loads. We feed two of the horses in the house with hay. We have seven
(continues on next page)

5260428/5252386/5278955.title: Livestock
5260428/5252386/5278955.text:
We have three cows at home. We put them in to the cow house in the Winter and leave them out in the fields in the Summer. We tie them with bails. The bails are made of timber. There are two beams of timber going from one end of the house to the other. There are two small ones going into the long one. The name of the cows are the short-horn, the grey and the red. We have five calves and two year-olds. The names
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210495/5279055.title: Farm Animals
5215784/5210495/5279055.text:
People in this district keep both horned and hornless cows. The latter they call maol cows. Long ago they used to keep Kerry cows which were small black cows with long horns. The old people called them Kilos. They were very good for supplying milk and butter. They were strange cows, for when calving they wished to be alone and always made for a shrubbery.Cows are generally tied to stakes in the stable by means of chains which are fastened
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210498/5279057.title: Hens and Chickens
5215784/5210498/5279057.text:
When a hen begins to clock I get from ten to fifteen eggs and I get a small box and put hay or straw into it. Then I fix the eggs into it. I put the hen in the box and cover her to keep her quiet. I take her out of the box every day to feed her and give her a drink. When the hen is lying on the eggs three weeks and the birds begin to leave the eggs she gets very hot and has to be taken out twice a day.Then when the chickens are out of the shells I feed them
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210660/5279153.title: Farm Animals
5215784/5210660/5279153.text:
We have four cows. We call one Poll, one of them Black tail, one the White horn. My mother milks them every morning and evening.She milks a few strands on the ground first for the fairies and she makes the sign of the cross on the cow's side in order to bless her.Long ago people used to tie a horse-shoe nail in a red rag on a cow's tail before she calved
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210685/5279187.title: Farm Animals
5215784/5210685/5279187.text:
Our cows names are Polly, Maolín and Short-horns. They have a stable for themselves, A piece of timber is inserted into the wall and an iron ring is put into it. A homemade rope is connected on to the ring and tied round the cow's neck.When the cows go into damage they are tied with a Crom-nasc round the horns and on to the hoof.Side langs and bootians
(continues on next page)

5215784/5210755/5279224.title: Hens
5215784/5210755/5279224.text:
We have about thirty hens at our house. We have black white red grey hens. They have a little house for themselves with perches going across from wall to wall and the hens roost on them every night.People do not like to put an even number of eggs under a hen because it is considered unlucky.Thirteen egg are always put down under a hen for a clutch. After three
(continues on next page)

5275203/5272360/5283584.title: Festival Customs
5275203/5272360/5283584.text:
(continued from previous page)
They are given sixpence or three pence in every house, and they buy lemonade or sweets with it.



The animals on our farm are as follows, calves, cows, sheep, horses, goats, pigs, and bullocks.These animals are very well cared for
(continues on next page)
